articles.headline: Market Forces Cited in Lymphoma Drugs’ Disuse
articles.snippet: Only about 10 percent of people who are suitable candidates for two drugs received one of them last year.
articles.abstract: Only about 10 percent of people who are suitable candidates for two drugs received one of them last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The patients’ stories sound nearly impossible.

articles.headline: Baseballs, Batteries and Bad Ads
articles.snippet: Is it cheating to write a “grab bag” column in the middle of July, when you’re days away from vacation?
articles.abstract: Is it cheating to write a “grab bag” column in the middle of July, when you’re days away from vacation?
articles.lead_paragraph: Is it cheating to write a “grab bag” column in the middle of July, when you’re days away from vacation, and you’re tired, oh-so-tired of waiting for the Bancroft family to make up its mind about Rupert Murdoch’s bid for Dow Jones? You be the judge.

articles.headline: Public Defenders Get Better Marks on Salary
articles.snippet: Lawyers paid by the hour achieve worse results for their clients and are more costly for taxpayers, a study found.
articles.abstract: Lawyers paid by the hour achieve worse results for their clients and are more costly for taxpayers, a study found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some poor people accused of federal crimes are represented by full-time federal public defenders who earn salaries, others by court-appointed lawyers who bill by the hour. A new study from an economist at Harvard says there is a surprisingly wide gap in how well the two groups perform.

articles.headline: Conrad Black’s Downfall Shaped by Many Battles
articles.snippet: Opportunism and indignation helped power Conrad M. Black’s rise to the heights of media life.
articles.abstract: Opportunism and indignation helped power Conrad M. Black’s rise to the heights of media life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Conrad M. Black showed a capacity for mixing mischief and capitalism at an early age: at 14, he was expelled from a Toronto private school for stealing copies of coming exams and selling them to his fellow students.

articles.headline: Conrad Black, Ex-Press Baron, Guilty of Fraud
articles.snippet: Hollinger International’s former head was convicted of taking illegal payments from the company.
articles.abstract: Hollinger International’s former head was convicted of taking illegal payments from the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Conrad M. Black, the Canadian-born press baron who cut a glittering swath through financial, political and high-society circles in Toronto, London and New York, was found guilty of fraud yesterday in a Chicago courtroom, along with three of his former employees.

articles.headline: In a Baghdad Killing, Questions That Haunt Iraq
articles.snippet: Khalid W. Hassan, an Iraqi reporter and interpreter for The Times, died in Iraq’s murderous turmoil.
articles.abstract: Khalid W. Hassan, an Iraqi reporter and interpreter for The Times, died in Iraq’s murderous turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, July 13 — At 8:45 a.m. on Friday, Khalid W. Hassan was navigating his car out of one of Baghdad’s most dangerous neighborhoods on his way to work as a reporter and interpreter at The New York Times bureau here. “My area is blocked,” he wrote in a cellphone text message to the paper’s newsroom manager. “I am trying to find a way out.”

articles.headline: Clinton Backer’s Ties to Powerful Cut Both Ways
articles.snippet: Vinod Gupta, a wealthy Democratic donor, is pulling back, saying that controversies have become too much.
articles.abstract: Vinod Gupta, a wealthy Democratic donor, is pulling back, saying that controversies have become too much.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many wealthy people have raised money for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign. But only Vinod Gupta has named a school building in India after her.

articles.headline: Maker Settles Suit on Device for Hearts
articles.snippet: Boston Scientific agreed to pay $195 million to settle claims related to a potentially flawed defibrillator made by its subsidiary, Guidant.
articles.abstract: Boston Scientific agreed to pay $195 million to settle claims related to a potentially flawed defibrillator made by its subsidiary, Guidant.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Boston Scientific Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $195 million to settle claims brought by thousands of heart patients who said they were not alerted to potential flaws in a defibrillator made by the Guidant Corporation, now a unit of Boston Scientific.

articles.headline: Emptying Nest Eggs, Not the Nests
articles.snippet: Like an allowance that extends far past adolescence, parents are helping finance their children’s lives longer, and depleting their retirement savings in the process.
articles.abstract: Like an allowance that extends far past adolescence, parents are helping finance their children’s lives longer, and depleting their retirement savings in the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sue and Bob Riccardi put their two children through school, and then some.

articles.headline: Pricing Pills by the Results
articles.snippet: Drug makers are exploring the possibility of tying pharmaceutical prices to performance.
articles.abstract: Drug makers are exploring the possibility of tying pharmaceutical prices to performance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Drug companies like to say that their most expensive products are fully worth their breathtaking prices. Now one company is putting its money where its mouth is — by offering a money-back guarantee.

articles.headline: Deal Reported in Abuse Cases in Los Angeles
articles.snippet: The settlement of $660 million will be by far the largest payout by any single Roman Catholic diocese in scandals over abuse by clergy members.
articles.abstract: The settlement of $660 million will be by far the largest payout by any single Roman Catholic diocese in scandals over abuse by clergy members.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for more than 500 people who say they were abused by Roman Catholic clergy members said last night that they had settled their lawsuits against the Archdiocese of Los Angeles for $660 million.

articles.headline: North Koreans Say They’ve Shut Nuclear Reactor
articles.snippet: The North Korean claim, synchronized with a shipment of fuel oil from South Korea, marked the first step toward reversing a confrontation with the U.S.
articles.abstract: The North Korean claim, synchronized with a shipment of fuel oil from South Korea, marked the first step toward reversing a confrontation with the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: North Korea told the United States yesterday that it had shut down its nuclear reactor at Yongbyon and readmitted a permanent international inspection team, completing its first step toward reversing a four-year-long confrontation with the United States during which the North has made fuel for a small but potent arsenal of nuclear weapons.

articles.headline: Toy Magnets Attract Sales, and Suits
articles.snippet: Magnetic toys have been ubiquitous at birthday parties for years. Now they are also appearing in lawsuits.
articles.abstract: Magnetic toys have been ubiquitous at birthday parties for years. Now they are also appearing in lawsuits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILLIAM FINLEY was almost 4 years old when his grandmother gave him a Magnetix building set for Christmas in 2004. Its colorful, tiny plastic rods, with powerful micro-magnets at each end that gripped shiny ball bearings, made the set a cool construction toy.

articles.headline: Windows Opening on the Royal Family’s Wealth
articles.snippet: As the family’s relationship with the public has been tested, the British royals have begun to offer peeks at the underpinnings of their fortune.
articles.abstract: As the family’s relationship with the public has been tested, the British royals have begun to offer peeks at the underpinnings of their fortune.
articles.lead_paragraph: London

articles.headline: Subprime, Subpar: For Sale?
articles.snippet: Some investors may think a buyout lies ahead for NovaStar Financial.
articles.abstract: Some investors may think a buyout lies ahead for NovaStar Financial.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOVASTAR FINANCIAL, a subprime mortgage originator based in Kansas City, Mo., has had its share of setbacks. That’s not surprising, given the carnage in its industry.

articles.headline: As Loved Ones Fight On, War Doubts Arise
articles.snippet: Continued chaos in Iraq, longer deployments and a rising death toll are causing weariness among military families.
articles.abstract: Continued chaos in Iraq, longer deployments and a rising death toll are causing weariness among military families.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT EUSTIS, Va., July 11 — Cpl. April Ponce De Leon describes herself and her husband as “gung-ho marines,” and in two weeks she deploys to Iraq, where her husband has been fighting since March.

articles.headline: The Richest of the Rich, Proud of a New Gilded Age
articles.snippet: Today’s titans often see themselves as pillars of a new age of prosperity, one in which their successes and philanthropy have made government less important.
articles.abstract: Today’s titans often see themselves as pillars of a new age of prosperity, one in which their successes and philanthropy have made government less important.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tributes to Sanford I. Weill line the walls of the carpeted hallway that leads to his skyscraper office, with its panoramic view of Central Park. A dozen framed magazine covers, their colors as vivid as an Andy Warhol painting, are the most arresting. Each heralds Mr. Weill’s genius in assembling Citigroup into the most powerful financial institution since the House of Morgan a century ago.

articles.headline: Russia Suspends Arms Agreement Over U.S. Shield
articles.snippet: Russia said it would suspend its obligations under a cold war-era arms control treaty over a missile shield plan.
articles.abstract: Russia said it would suspend its obligations under a cold war-era arms control treaty over a missile shield plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, July 14 — President Vladimir V. Putin, angered by American plans to deploy a missile shield in Eastern Europe, formally notified NATO governments on Saturday that Russia will suspend its obligations under the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty, a key cold war-era arms limitation agreement.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Ford Is Said to Consider Selling Off Its Volvo Brand
articles.snippet: The decision to talk to interested buyers comes as Ford also is trying to sell its two other European luxury brands, Jaguar and Land Rover.
articles.abstract: The decision to talk to interested buyers comes as Ford also is trying to sell its two other European luxury brands, Jaguar and Land Rover.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich., July 15  — The Ford Motor Company, which is struggling to reorganize amid record losses and slumping American sales, has decided to entertain offers for Volvo, people with knowledge of the situation said Sunday.

articles.headline: Japan Learns Dreaded Task of Jury Duty
articles.snippet: Preparing to adopt jury-style trials in 2009, Japan is holding mock trials to overcome cultural obstacles.
articles.abstract: Preparing to adopt jury-style trials in 2009, Japan is holding mock trials to overcome cultural obstacles.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAGANO, Japan — The two-day mock trial resembled, more often than not, a college seminar with the three judges acting as professors and the six jurors as freshmen. Sitting stiffly around an oval table, they were deliberating whether the defendant had intended to kill a taxi driver in a botched robbery.

articles.headline: Casinos Boom in Katrina’s Wake as Cash Pours In
articles.snippet: Business in the gambling halls of New Orleans and Biloxi, Miss., has reached an all-time high in recent months.
articles.abstract: Business in the gambling halls of New Orleans and Biloxi, Miss., has reached an all-time high in recent months.
articles.lead_paragraph: BILOXI, Miss. — This seaside gambling resort along a stretch of the Gulf Coast, sometimes called the “redneck Riviera,” has 40 percent fewer hotel rooms and only two-thirds as many slot machines as it did before Hurricane Katrina. A major bridge that connects the casinos in this popular tourist destination to Alabama, the Florida Panhandle and other points east remains closed, and Mayor A. J. Holloway estimates that as many as 15 percent of the city’s pre-Katrina residents still have not returned.

articles.headline: High Wattage at Sun Valley, but No Deals
articles.snippet: At Allen & Company’s rarefied annual summit for media moguls, the titans arrived, the guest list shimmered, but the deals didn’t happen.
articles.abstract: At Allen & Company’s rarefied annual summit for media moguls, the titans arrived, the guest list shimmered, but the deals didn’t happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are a few givens at Allen & Company’s rarefied annual summit for media moguls in Sun Valley, Idaho. Titans arrive in a conga line of private jets, attend some gold-plated panels followed by cocktails, and occasionally head out to the paths of the Sun Valley Resort for a little speed-dating. The guest list is always incandescent — hey, there’s Bill Gates! Tony Blair! Rupert Murdoch! — and the air is thick with rumors of deals.

articles.headline: Book Brings Penguins Into Boardrooms
articles.snippet: Last year, John P. Kotter rewrote his 1996 book about organizational change, recasting it as a fable about penguins. Since then it has sold some 224,000 copies.
articles.abstract: Last year, John P. Kotter rewrote his 1996 book about organizational change, recasting it as a fable about penguins. Since then it has sold some 224,000 copies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until recently, John P. Kotter was known in business circles as a well-respected author of management books and a longtime professor at Harvard Business School.

articles.headline: Solar Power Wins Enthusiasts but Not Money
articles.snippet: Experts say that moving solar energy from niche to mainstream is unlikely without big breakthroughs.
articles.abstract: Experts say that moving solar energy from niche to mainstream is unlikely without big breakthroughs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trade association for the nuclear power industry recently asked 1,000 Americans what energy source they thought would be used most for generating electricity in 15 years. The top choice? Not nuclear plants, or coal or natural gas. The winner was the sun, cited by 27 percent of those polled.
articles.byline: By Andrew C. Revkin and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: The Hand That Controls the Sock Puppet Could Get Slapped
articles.snippet: A handful of prominent individuals have been caught creating fake online identities to praise, defend or create the illusion of support for themselves or their companies.
articles.abstract: A handful of prominent individuals have been caught creating fake online identities to praise, defend or create the illusion of support for themselves or their companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 — On the Internet nobody knows you’re a dog — or the chief executive of a Fortune 500 company.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Aid to Pakistan in Tribal Areas Raises Concerns
articles.snippet: The United States plans to pour $750 million into a lawless region over the next five years, but critics fear that the money might fall into the wrong hands.
articles.abstract: The United States plans to pour $750 million into a lawless region over the next five years, but critics fear that the money might fall into the wrong hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: GHALANAI, Pakistan — The United States plans to pour $750 million of aid into Pakistan’s tribal areas over the next five years as part of a “hearts and minds” campaign to win over this lawless region from Qaeda and Taliban militants.

articles.headline: Mistrust as Iraqi Troops Encounter New U.S. Allies
articles.snippet: As the U.S. builds alliances with ex-insurgents, the gulf remains vast between the Sunnis and the Iraqi Army, with U.S. troops sometimes having to intercede.
articles.abstract: As the U.S. builds alliances with ex-insurgents, the gulf remains vast between the Sunnis and the Iraqi Army, with U.S. troops sometimes having to intercede.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASR WA SALAM, Iraq, July 10 — Abu Azzam says the 2,300 men in his movement include members of fierce Sunni groups like the 1920s Revolutionary Brigade and the Mujahedeen Army that have fought the American occupation. Now his men patrol alongside the Americans, who want to turn them into a security force that can bring peace to this stretch between Baghdad and Falluja.

articles.headline: Chief of Universal Finds Success at the Back of the Pack
articles.snippet: Though profitable for the last nine years, Universal has been noticeably short on blockbusters to call its own. And that is largely by design.
articles.abstract: Though profitable for the last nine years, Universal has been noticeably short on blockbusters to call its own. And that is largely by design.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 15 — The hilltop theme park outside the 14th floor office of Ron Meyer, president of the Universal Studios Group, anchored by past glories like its “Jurassic Park” and “Backdraft” rides, could stand a makeover.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: A New Populism Spurs Democrats on the Economy
articles.snippet: The more populist tone is one indication of a broader debate among Democrats over how much they should break with the centrism of the Clinton years.
articles.abstract: The more populist tone is one indication of a broader debate among Democrats over how much they should break with the centrism of the Clinton years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15 — On Capitol Hill and on the presidential campaign trail, Democrats are increasingly moving toward a full-throated populist critique of the current economy.
